H0.text: Visible light represents only a very small portion of the spectrum, with wavelengths from 400–700 nm.

H1.text: Invisible light represents only a very small portion of the spectrum with wavelengths from 400‑700 nm.

H2.text: Sunlight represents only a very small portion of the spectrum with wavelengths from 400‑700 nm.

H3.text: Ultraviolet light represents only a very small portion of the spectrum whose wavelengths range from 400 to 700 nanometers.

A4.text: The optical spectrum is sometimes considered to be the same as the visible spectrum, but some authors define the term more broadly, to include the ultraviolet and infrared parts of the electromagnetic spectrum as well, known collectively as optical radiation.

A5.text: A typical human eye will respond to wavelengths from about 380 to about 750 nanometers.
